posts.name: David Smith
posts.cooked: Next month there will be 402 Million Internet Users In India and India will become the 2nd-largest internet user base in the world only next to China. Nigeria has about 7.1 million daily facebook users, but India has about 59 million daily facebook users and it is increasing. I've read many articles/webpages that have compared Nigerian's Internet Market to Indian's Internet Market and some agree that they are similar while some haven't. If they are similar in (culture, technology, traditional ways and etc), wouldn't it be wise if Nigerian Services/Startups targeted Indian's Market since India has more internet customers/users than Nigeria? Like will it be easier/quicker to make more money from India's internet customers/users? Create a local/localized app/service/startup for Nigeria, clone it and adjust it for India.

posts.cooked:
Got this email from Leadway Insurance trying to sell funeral insurance. I think they got a few things wrong but you guys be the judges.

  1. they sent the email from funeral@leadway.com. As soon as I saw that, I thought WTF!
  2. I don't remember signing up for any Leadway newsletter
  3. I think they focused too much on the financial aspect of this thing. Africans don't think anyone will die; and definitely don't plan for it. I suspect there's a much better way to sell this. Something along the lines of "losing an elderly loved one is always sad; but Leadway can help you give them a befitting burial".
  4. This email was almost gleeful - "Grab this offer NOW!" Really?

Anyway, read the mail and I'd love to hear how you think email marketing can be improved.

Do you know that with as little as *N5000 monthly, you can access as much as N1million as payout for funeral benefits in the event you lose an elderly loved one?
You will get to choose the particular relative(s) to be covered (parents and/or parents in-laws) and you decide the level of benefit to be covered. You also have the option to access more than N1million as death benefit.
Premiums payment only runs for a very short time after which your payments stop and we will pay you the N1million benefit for ALL the lives, whenever this event occurs in the future for each life insured.
Having carefully profiled you, Leadway recommends this special product offer to you, which has been designed to address any unforeseen financial worries in the event of the loss of loved ones. Simply click here and sign up. It's that easy!
Give us a call and we assure you proper detailing to help your understanding. Grab this offer NOW.
posts.blurb: ...a befitting burial ". This email was almost gleeful - " Grab this offer NOW! " Really? Anyway, read the mail and I'd love to hear how you think email marketing can be improved. Do you know that with as little as *N5000 monthly, you can access as much as N1million as payout for funeral benefits in the ev...

posts.name: Oyihoma Saleh
posts.cooked:
I first made this comment on radar about the harm online marketplaces in Nigeria are having on eCommerce a few months ago...

A guide to building marketplaces

I've noticed that online marketplaces as opposed to true E-commerce websites seems to be what every company is switching to today. Jumia, Konga, DealDey, Vconnet etc. It is obviously much more cost effective for these big players and for the sellers that list their inventory on these sites it surely is a way to boost sales. However, I can't help but think that in the long run this is going to hurt these sellers in terms of scaling and growing an actual brand in Nigeria. Many simply operate the…

With Konga recently announcing the continuation of their restructuring initiative to pivot to the marketplace model, I think it's important to have the conversation of the impact these marketplaces are having on eCommerce.

Here is my opinion piece on Why Online Marketplaces are not helping eCommerce grow in Nigeria.

Thoughts and opinions?

posts.name: Hanzo Hasashi
posts.cooked:
If you are not already aware of it, you will be soon. It seems the Pokemons are back and they've literally taken over the world. Again. This time with an augmented reality game.

What is especially inspiring about this takeover is that they are not spending bucketloads of money on traditional app advertising like Clash of Clans, Mobile Strike, etc, but somehow within 3 days of since their July 6 launch, they've got everyone talking about them, sharing real life stores, and spreading organically like wildfire.

I've read stories such as

Today, I was driving with my little brother when out of nowhere he yelled at me to stop. Thinking it was urgent, I slammed my breaks, almost getting rammed from behind. Why did he yell for me to stop? The Pokémon GO said there was a sparrow near us.

and

Australian police warning users not to physically enter the police station when collecting items

and

Pokemon Go put me in the ER last night,” read one post on the Pokemon Go subreddit. “Not even 30 minutes after the release last night, I slipped and fell down a ditch,” said the Reddit user. “Fractured the fifth metatarsal bone in my foot, 6-8 weeks for recovery. I told all the doctors I was walking my dog

The launch has even made Nintendo's stock pop.

I think the key lesson for entrepreneurs is that we are beginning to see the end of traditional digital advertising and the true emergence of what social viral advertising, where the creative (i.e. ad) is dynamic, native, and value driven, and the distribution is largely or completely crowd sourced. I for one am looking deeply into how this particular execution is unfolding and hope to learn some valuable lessons from the orchestrators i.e geniuses behind it.

So who's going to lose out in this new world order?

  1. Those that think it is okay to plaster your site with ads
  2. Those that rely on massive billboard and TV budgets.
  3. Those CMOs that are not judged by their ROI and who think a multi-million naira marketing budget is the key to success.

That Pokemon GO is going to be the app of the year is increasing indisputable. What is more interesting is to observe its impact on digital marketing in the years to come.

Thoughts?
posts.blurb: ...ur site with ads Those that rely on massive billboard and TV budgets. Those CMOs that are not judged by their ROI and who think a multi-million naira marketing budget is the key to success. That Pokemon GO is going to be the app of the year is increasing indisputable. What is more interesting is to obse...

posts.name: Oluwole
posts.cooked:
Today, we have more founders who are building their startups on blind guesses, wild assumptions and vanity metrics. (little wonder, our startups' failure rate is HIGH)

The chances of growing scalable startups without a data-driven approach and growth teams is near Zero. So, it occurred to me that we need more people to fill this skill gap to help our startups become sustainable.

  • Is there are person worthy of mention that you know that is leading growth in his company?
  • Do you know of trainings focused on analytics and growth marketing in Nigeria?

Please weigh in your thoughts.

P.S: I am looking at some smart people like @freshboi_ekundayo with side-eye already

posts.name: Humphrey
posts.cooked:
Ever wondered why GTB created SME MarketHub when there are other problems they could solve. It was a bit of a joke when they started but to be honest they should not be running an e-commerce platform. What's the point of a big bank setting up an e-commerce platform? This shows our mentality to a certain degree. "Everyone has an e-commerce platform, I will do my own'. Yet we complain about the influx of foreign apps loaded with non-nigerian investors' dollars and pounds. Agreed a lot of the local apps are not too great (to put it mildly) but they could do with some help from our local investors too.

Nigerian startups need funding to survive and scale. Retail businesses need adequate payment channels for their businesses. What are the banks doing about these problems?

I was going to mention this in one of my comments on the post "uber is killing our local startups" but I think its worth discussing our 'local' problems/challenges.

GTB should be supporting local startups. They may be doing this already maybe I ma not just aware of it. If you have received any kind of funding from banks particularly GTB, it will be nice to know.

posts.name: I Orb Therefore I Am
posts.cooked:
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and his partner Priscilla Chan announced the birth of their baby, Max, with a letter detailing their plans for a new charity initiative.

As part of the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative, the couple will fund disease research, they wrote in the note.

"Our initial areas of focus will be personalized learning, curing disease, connecting people and building strong communities," they wrote.

Zuckerberg and Chan pledged to give 99% of their Facebook shares, worth about $45 billion, to the initiative, with likely a few billion of that going toward developing cures for diseases.

"Once we recognize that your generation and your children's generation may not have to suffer from disease, we collectively have a responsibility to tilt our investments a bit more towards the future to make this reality. Your mother and I want to do our part."

Zuckerberg and Chan were pragmatic about advancing disease treatments and cures.

"Curing disease will take time. Over short periods of five or ten years, it may not seem like we're making much of a difference. But over the long term, seeds planted now will grow, and one day, you or your children will see what we can only imagine: a world without suffering from disease."

With $45 billion to give away, and with health research getting some part of that, the world likely be a healthier place for baby Max.

Source: http://read.bi/1HFSpzX

posts.name: Uzo Olisemeka
posts.cooked:
I built something for a friend.

They had a problem in their line of business. It wasn't a major problem. Or maybe it was one they didn't realize they could solve with software.

Either way, they had a problem and I built something to solve it.

After checking online, I see software of this sort exists, but nothing modern-looking. Everything looks like it was built in the mid 90s and never revisited. But there are quite a few that do exactly what mine does.

My problem is I haven't been able to identify who actually buys it. People clearly had a problem to solve and a few solutions exist, but I've only been able to identify two industries (one being my friend's industry) where they need what I have.

I'd like to believe it's a matter of me being absolutely shit at marketing, research and everything related, so I wanted to find out from Radar how you guys do market research.

If you have a product, how do you identify who could be in need of it?

The tech space has always aligned just coding with tech. My opinion is digital marketing is also tech. We help coders understand the best ways to sell their coded software as well as analyze all analyzables.

"It's 10 times easier to find competent programmers in Nigeria than competent digital marketers" - Mark Essien, December 2015

We are a very scarce commodity.

Bottom line: Do we have any Nigerian digital marketer on Radar?

posts.name: Kola Ibrahim
posts.cooked:
Continuing the discussion from Managing Tech "Co-founder" offers. How do you deal with it?:

First things first, if someone can code it, YOU can code it..............at least an MVP.

Secondly, Technical Co-Founders are overated...You dont need one, for reasons that will be explained below.

When you have an idea, do the below.

  1. get a piece of paper, preferably A3.

  2. draw out how you want the client facing interface to look like.

  3. write out a step by step workflow, starting from No 1, of how a client will sign up, and use your solution (algorithm)

  4. Re-write no 3, until the workflow is Lucid.

  5. go to producthunt.com, search for startup tools.

  6. go to medium.com, search for startup tools.

  7. Whatever tools you get in no 6 and no 7 will be enough for you to build an MVP.

  8. Create a landing page.

  9. advertise via twitter,fb,ig,nairaland,radar, and google ads.

  10. continue to tweak the app.

  11. Hire a marker, sales person.

  12. hire coders off elance to retweak your MVP.

  13. Recruit a Marketing/sales/biz dev cofounder.

  14. If you achieve scale, build a team of coders.

  15. You dont need a tech-cofounder.

  16. You need a marketing -Cofounder.

It is actually naive to think someone you dont know from adam will build something for you free of charge, the best thing you can get is free advice if you rub minds on a forum like this.

More importantly, it is CATASTROPHIC to build a solution, and not be able to succeed because you do not have a Marketing /Sales GURU on your team.

Some startups focus on the wrong things, marketing should be your first priority, once you get that right, you can always kaizen your low cost MVP.
posts.blurb: ...enough for you to build an MVP. Create a landing page. advertise via twitter,fb,ig,nairaland,radar, and google ads. continue to tweak the app. Hire a marker, sales person. hire coders off elance to retweak your MVP. Recruit a Marketing/sales/biz dev cofounder. If you achieve scale, build a team of coder...

posts.name: Chigoziri Okeke
posts.cooked:
Hi radarians, I'm currently working on this idea and I would like your honest criticism - it doesn't matter if you're gonna bite at it or side with it. All we need is your criticisms. Thank you.

MarketSquare is an online platform (web and mobile) that would help students sell off items they no longer need or buy the ones they couldn’t afford, find spaces for rent around their campuses and connect business owners with customers around a particular campus.

MarketSquare was born out of the need to proffer solutions to the untold difficulties that students face while trying to perform certain essential tasks for survival on campus. We are out to take care of these bugging, time-consuming and stressful tasks - ranging from finding spaces for rent, selling off used properties, going to the market, finding roommates, getting quality used stuffs at cheaper rates, placing and receiving orders from dealers nationwide and so much more.
Our mission at the end is to help the average Nigerian student reduce stress and focus more on achieving an excellent academic performance.

MarketSquare offers 3 workable solutions all in one. They include –

SQUARE ITEMS – a classifieds where users can either post ads of items they wish to sell off or search for items they wish to buy.

SQUARE SHOPS – a platform where business owners, service providers and student entrepreneurs can put and manage their businesses online.

SQUARE ACCOMMODATIONS – a platform that will make finding spaces for rent very easy for students and other tenants alike.

posts.name: David Smith
posts.cooked:
Original Link To Article

Based on this post by Oo Nwoye, I would like to expound a bit on what I think the best approach is.

First of all, let's look at what the problem is. The problem are these:

Nigerians do not use post codes
Nigerian streets are ambiguous
There is no central way of retrieving all the streets in Nigeria
Street houses are not numbered correctly
You cannot recognize if streets are close to each other
Very long roads cannot be further broken down into pieces (as is possible where post-codes are used)
The post-code allocation system is not expanding as quickly as the country is developing.
SUGGESTION FOR SOLVING THE ABOVE
An API is created that does the following:

It lists all the streets and houses within a post-code
It can receive an unstructured address, and return a valid address suggestion.
It can provide the GPS location of a particular street at well as the GPS of a particular house number
It provides address suggestions given partial information
It stores meta information about a street, e.g It is 'Off which road?'. How do people refer to it commonly, e.g 'Masha', 'Alhaji Masha', 'Masha Road', 'Marsha'?
WHAT WOULD BE THE UTILITY?
a. For an e-commerce store, when customers enter their address, they call this API to provide auto-suggestions, and can then provide a valid and known street name to the user. This way, deliveries will tend to arrive better at the correct destination.

b. For software that needs to know what is close to a street, e.g a 'Nearest Hospital' app, it can use the post-code to pull all the nearby streets which can access that hospital

c. For people that need to find particular addresses, e.g a bank is looking for 48c Ogbor Hill, Aba - the API would provide them the exact GPS location of that house.

HOW WOULD IT WORK?
On the backend, there is a key-store db, e.g MongoDB. It stores a bunch of information about the street and the area.

As requests for street name information hit the API, the API starts using that information to build a comprehensive list of road names. This way, even if only one e-commerce store is using it, given enough time, it will have gained a lot of information about streets.

A clever algorithm at the back takes the names users are typing and resolves them into a single 'Master' name that represents the best guess for the name.

This can be combined with a manual intervention method where people help to clean up the street data.

For the e-commerce store, there is no UI change or disruption, as the user only sees suggestions when there is enough information on the backend. Over time, this db will grow to become comprehensive, and there will be an open source database of all street names in Nigeria, their post-codes and all valid addresses on those streets.

This db will be live and will grow and adapt naturally as the environment changes.

posts.name: Udeme Samuel
posts.cooked:
So Andela was funded and then Mark Zuckerberg made his announcement, in it this content stuck my mind to comment from the soul.

I was lucky to be born in a wealthy country where I had access to computers and the internet. If I had been born somewhere else, I'm not sure I would have been able to start Facebook -- or at least it would have taken a lot longer and been more difficult. Mark Zuckerberg

Mark Zuckerberg nice work with facebook, you have no idea what it means to be developer from africa talk less of an entrepreneur from Africa (Nigeria), because you never grew up here, have never been there and may never be. Opportunities is scarce here, No electricity, No water, High cost of internet (These are no excuses, this is reality). In simple terms everything around you will literally kill you as a developer from this part of the world http://cnn.it/1EvSIoA or my version http://bit.ly/1Uc8FsL , I don't see new developers surviving well from Nigeria my country i see a few at a broader scale, instead why not use your influence to introduce Modern Computer skills, programming into universities, polytechnics and most especially colleges of education, that will have a greater impact on the local tech ecosystem and at a broader view Fortune 500 companies, in other issues i dont support the facebook free basics,

First of all telcos are still charging to use facebook or other included services offerings, so where is the free in the access.

Secondly what are you doing to include the local tech startups to the free basics because your service is disrupting some local startups services.

All the same Facebook is cool and a new digital culture and innovation is having a greater application here in africa than in silicon valley. you can continue the conversation on radar you will meet same like local developers http://bit.ly/24UXTMF, it is a challenge if you will gladly accept (Let us wish he will come to radar).

It might not be a comprehensive enough review but we sure touched a lot of markers that will make tech in Nigeria in 2016. Happy New Year!

posts.cooked:
Within our growing start up community in Nigeria, I feel 2015 was the year of the software engineer. Much of our conversations, thoughts and perhaps recruiting were shaped around software engineering and product. There were more hackathons than ever before and the 'learn how to code' flag was flown all year round, (this is a good thing).

I’m praying 2016 is the year of the unconventional marketer/ growth hacker and sales/business developer. Any startup that intends to grow and succeed will need to search high and low for talent in this area, as I know from first hand experience it's scarce.

If you are not an engineer and want to make yourself valuable and build a career in a potentially successful start up or even start a startup - become either

  1. A growth hacker - in every sense of the word (not just a SEO/social media manager that can only deliver results with Rocket/Konga type marketing budgets)

  2. Business development / Sales specialist - the type that truly understands and enjoys the entire sales cycle and can close both simple and complex deals.

Think about it, you may be more successful and sought after as 1 of 5 Growth marketing specialists for startups and SME’s in the health care space than.... the 2000th average engineer in the e-commerce space?

Anyhow if your looking for an opportunity in either of the two areas mentioned above, holla at me f[at]studysearch.co !! My answer to the question, no one wins, its a combination of skills not a competition.

posts.cooked:
Hello All, I stumbled upon this forum and I'm excited to be part of your community. Although I do not have a tech background, I love to follow Tech news and regularly read Techcabal for the latest on Nigeria's Tech scene. Our company, Partboyz Auto Parts (www.partboyz.com) is a retailer of auto parts. Recently we launched our ecommerce site and with zero budget on online marketing, SEO or PPC have been generating significant online orders (actual purchases). We quickly realized the potential of online marketing and we are set to double down on the sales funnel that have worked for us thus far.

As I mentioned, we are a retailer of auto parts and have grown to 6 retail outlets in Lagos and Abuja. Our goal is to become the Autozone of Nigeria. Having realized the potential of the internet to add scale and efficiencies to our industry, we have decided to take the bull by the horn and build www.autoselect.ng an online marketplace dedicated to auto parts, in the style of ebay motors parts marketplace (The website is under construction presently) Below is a link to an article I shared on LinkedIn yesterday. I invite your comments, insights and advice on best practices.
"Autoselect.ng - Building Nigeria's online marketplace for auto parts" https://lnkd.in/drj78sj on @LinkedIn

posts.name: Silas Okwoche
posts.cooked:
A short short time ago.. in a galaxy not so far away (Lagos)... one young tech company overthrew the empire is striving to build awesome amazing things that will make a difference. And so we are currently seeking for a handful of bright graduate interns to join our team.

[Graduate Intern defn : noun - Some one that is generally between university and NYSC or sort-of in NYSC]

We are looking to hire FULLTIME interns for UI/UX/Graphic design, PHP/JS development, on-the-ground bizdev & then digital marketing.

Here are the general requirements:
- You've got to be smart and own some kind of smartphone
- You've got to love technology in general & have a laptop at your disposal
- You got to be super comfortable with the internet and social media.
- You've got to be creative, open minded, play well on team or go solo to get something done when neccessary.

(You probably have all this on lockdown on your CV already, so unto the specific stuff)

Here are the specific requirements;

UI/UX/Graphic design

  • Strong use of graphic applications i.e. Fireworks, Photoshop or Corel
  • Good knowledge of design concepts (material design etc)
  • Able to dream up stellar graphical communications
  • Basic HTML & motion graphics knowledge is an added advantage.

PHP/JS development

  • Very good knowledge of the PHP /MySQL
  • Good use of PHP frameworks (Cake, MVC)
  • Comfortable with PHP CMS's (Wordpress)
  • Very good knowledge of Javascript (use of AngularJS, Cordova is an added advantage)

BizDev

  • Good knowledge of project management
    *Good knowledge developing/executing marketing campaigns
  • Strong oral & written communication skills
  • Ability to design and deliver awesome presentations and business documents
  • Good negotiation and sale closure skills

Digital Marketing

  • Strong use of Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
  • Great at spotting viral trends early and leveraging on them
  • Must be brilliant at copy writing and story telling
  • Be familiar with PPC, SEO etc
  • Be a working meme idea generator

We're basically not so concerned with what college you went to, or your last CGPA, we are seeking diamonds in the not-so-rough... so if you fit this bill then send links to your portfolio, your CV (and/or other documents that showcases your talent) as well as your social media profile links to mail(at) nervemobile(dot) com.

PS:
We'll get to Google-style perks soon , but till then, we'll pay a decent allowance, plus access to a corporate mini library, a mini-mini gym, interesting trainings & off-course PS/Netflix.
If this isn't for you then tell someone you know... and may the Force be with you!

Perks associated with registered accounts include saving download links of previous purchases and access to 'GidiBooks Funds' which is basically a topup functionality. Merchants take 90%.

Functionality feedbacks or ideas if you have the time. Thank you.

Also, you could try out the service with this short story I wrote for this purpose. A Little Too Late. It's free.

posts.name: Felix Obinna
posts.cooked:
Hello Radarians.

I'm about launching a product of mine, and we 're setting out to bring marketers on board.
But, as it is, we are looking at having our marketers work on a commission basis.
Well, we 're not planning to have it based on commission completely though.

This is how we intend to run it: The service is supposed to run on commission. We are to collect 15% of every transaction carried out on our system. But, for the first 2 -3 months, we want to forfeit the commission.

The marketers will be provided with coupon cards that gives 10% off every first transaction of the user.
Each marketer will have a different coupon code so that we can easily track each of 'em.
Then, the other 5% goes to the marketer.

Reasons being that the marketer would, on his or on her own would target the high paying customers
which will be of advantage to us.
And, again, we 're running on a low budget.
And, we 'll have a base salary for the marketers(though it may not be much).

Do you think this model will work?
If not, why?
And, please, what do you advice?
